body.p: The purpose of this activity is to give you guided practice in carrying out the two-sample t-test, and to show you how to use software to aid in the process.

A study was conducted at a large state university in order to compare the sleeping habits of undergraduate students to those of graduate students. Random samples of 75 undergraduate students and 50 graduate students were chosen and each of the subjects was asked to report the number of hours he or she sleeps in a typical day. The thought was that since undergraduate students are generally younger and party more during their years in school, they sleep less, on average, than graduate students. Do the data support this hypothesis? The following figure summarizes the problem:

image.alt: Our categorical variable, Type of student (X), has two categories: Undergraduate and Graduate Students. From this, we create two populations, population 1 for undergraduate students and population 2 for graduate students. Each population has its own hours of sleep (Y) mean: μ_1 for population 1 and μ_2 for population 2. For each population, we create a SRS. From population 1 a SRS of size 75 is created. For population 2, a SRS of size 50 is created.

body.p: μ1—the mean number of hours undergraduate students sleep in a typical day
μ2—the mean number of hours graduate students sleep in a typical day
Comment: Before we move on to carry out the test, it is important to realize that in the two-sample problem, the data can be provided in three possible ways:

(i) Sample data in one column, and another column that indicates which sample the observation belongs to. Recall that this is the way the data were given in our leading example (looks vs. personality score and gender):
Note that essentially, one column contains the explanatory variable, and one contains the response.
(ii) Sample data in different columns—data from each of the two samples appear in a column dedicated to that category. As you'll see, this is the way the data are provided in this example:

image.alt: A table with two columns. The column headings are "Undergraduate" and "Graduate." Each column is a list of collected data for the respective category. For example, the undergraduate column contains 6, 5, 3, 6, and so on, representing the first 4 data points for undergraduates.

body.p: (iii) Summarized data—we are not given the actual data, but just the data summaries: sample sizes, sample means and sample standard deviations of both samples. Recall that in our second example, the data were given in this format.

image.alt: A table describing the following data: 20-29 yrs old: n = 712, y-bar = 83.4, S = 18.7 75+ yrs old: n = 1001, y-bar = 78.5, S = 19.0

alternative.title: R Instructions
alternative.p: To carry out the test, open R with the data set preloaded by right-clicking here and choosing "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in R.
The data have been loaded into the data frame sleep. The two variables in the data frame are undergraduate and graduate.
To carry out the t-test, enter the command:

Note: Using R, when we used t.test() for a one-sample t-test in a previous activity, we specified a one-sample data set, a hypothetical mean, and an alternative hypothesis. To perform a two-sample t-test, we use the same command, t.test(), but specify two sample data sets and an alternative hypothesis. If the data set were structured so the sample data is in one column (called sleep) and another column that indicates which sample the observation belongs to (called student.type), then the command would be t.test(sleep~student.type, alternative="less").

alternative.title: StatCrunch Instructions
alternative.p: To open this file in StatCrunch you must first right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Next click here to open StatCrunch in a separate window and login using your username and password.

ul.li: Click on the link “Open StatCrunch” at the top of the My StatCrunch page.
To open the data set select the “My computer” link under Load a data set from box on the left side of the page.
Select the "Browse" or “Choose File” (depending on which browser you're using and select the data set you downloaded
Scroll to the bottom of the page and click on “Load File”

alternative.p: Choose: Stat → T statistics → Two sample → with data (or with summary if summarized data)
Choose among the following three options, depending on what format the data are given in.

ul.li: Samples in one column—enter the column where the samples are, twice and each time use the Where option to limit which values are being grouped.
Samples in different columns—enter the columns where the data are
Summarized data--- enter the sample means, sample standard deviations and sample sizes of both samples
Press Next
Select appropriate form of hypothesis test
Press Calculate

alternative.title: Minitab Instructions
alternative.p: To carry out the test, launch Minitab with the data in the worksheet and follow the instructions below.

To open Minitab with the data in the worksheet, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Minitab. Note: a dialog box will likely appear that says "A copy of the content of this file will be added to the current project"—just click "OK."

ul.li: Choose: Stat → Basic Statistics → 2-Sample t

Choose among the following three options, depending on what format the data are given in.
Samples in one column—enter the column where the samples (Y) are and the one where the subscripts are (X).
Samples in different columns—enter the columns where the data are
Summarized data—enter the sample sizes, sample means and sample standard deviations of both samples.
Click on "Options" to select the appropriate alternative.
Click "OK" twice.

alternative.title: Excel 2013 and 2016 Instructions
alternative.p: To carry out the test, launch Excel with the data in the worksheet and follow the instructions below.
To open the dataset, click here to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and double-click it to open it in Excel. When Excel opens you may have to enable editing.
First we must establish the null and alternative hypotheses.
We are using a one-sided alternative hypothesis because we suspect that undergraduates get less sleep on average than graduates.
To carry out the two sample t-test we will use the the following formula:

ul.li: After you open the data in Excel, go to an empty cell and type ybar1 (sample mean of the undergraduates). In the two cells to the right of this, type sd1 (sample standard deviation of the undergraduates) and n1 (sample size of the undergraduates) respectively. In the cells below starting with the cell below ybar1, type =AVERAGE(A2:A76), =STDEV.S(A2:A76), and =COUNT(A2:A76)

Now go to another empty cell and type ybar2 (sample mean of the graduates). In the two cells to the right of this, type sd2 (sample standard deviation of the graduates) and n2 (sample size of the graduates) respectively. In the cells below starting with the cell below ybar2, type AVERAGE(B2:B51) =STDEV.S(B2:B51), and =COUNT(B2:B51).

Use the given formula to calculate the test statistic t. You can use the cells that you created earlier for the needed values. To enter formula type (E2-E4)/SQRT(F2^2/G2+F4^2/G4). In this example the ybar1 value is assumed to be in cell E2. Note that your cell locations may be different depending on where you put ybar1.

Finally, use the test statistic t to calculate the p-value. Use the Excel function T.DIST(t, degrees of freedom (n-1), cumulative). Here we use the smaller of the two sample sizes for the degrees of freedom. Since the graduate sample had 50 which is smaller than 75, we would use 49 as the degrees of freedom. Type TRUE for cumulative.

alternative.title: TI Instructions
alternative.p: To open a group of lists with the data loaded, right-click here and choose "Save Target As" to download the file to your computer. Then find the downloaded file and send it to your calculator. For instructions on how to connect your calculator to your computer and transfer a file, click here.

p.em: Two-sample t-test for two independent means

ul.li: Choose STAT/TESTS/4:2-SampTTest.
Note: Use arrows to navigate through the menu.
Inpt: Since you are given the sample data, choose Data.
List1: L1, press 2ND/1.
List2: L2, press 2ND/2.
Freq1: 1 (the number one).
Freq2: 1 (the number one).
Choose the correct form of the alternative hypothesis (≠, <, >).
Choose Pooled:No since we are assuming unequal variances.
Arrow down and choose CALCULATE.
Press ENTER.
